close.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to shut something in order to cover an opening, or to become shut in this way
close.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Would you mind if I closed the window?
Let me do the car door – it won’t close properly.
Beth closed her eyes and tried to sleep.
She heard the door close behind her.
close.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move the parts of something together so that there is no longer a space between them
close.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Anne closed her book and stood up.
close.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if a shop or building closes, or you close it, it stops being open to the public for a period of time
close.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Harry usually closes the store completely when he goes on vacation.
close.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if a company, shop etc closes, or you close it, it stops operating permanently
close.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: We have reluctantly decided to close the factory.
The shop closed down some time last year.
close.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to end or to make something end, especially in a particular way
close.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: In her closing remarks, the judge urged the jury to consider the facts only.
I will now close the meeting by asking you to join me in a final toast.
The movie closes with an emotional reunion in Prague.
close.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to be worth a particular amount of money at the end of a day’s trading (=the buying and selling of shares) on the stock exchange
close.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The dollar closed at 64p against the pound.
close.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to finish on a particular date
close.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Our special offer closes on June 3.
close.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to make the distance or difference between two things smaller
close.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: an attempt to close the gap between the rich and poor
The other car was closing on us fast.
close.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to make taking part in an activity or using an opportunity no longer possible
close.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Bidding for the painting will close on Friday.
The country has now closed its borders to all foreign nationals  (=will not let foreigners in).
The legislation aims to close a lot of legal loopholes.
close.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if someone’s hands, arms etc close around something, or are closed around something, they hold it firmly
close.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Her left hand closed over his arm.
She closed her hand tightly around her bag.
close.translation[0].definitions[10].def: if a wound closes, or if someone closes it, the edges grow together again or are sewn together
close.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: The surgeon closed the incision neatly.
close.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: Close belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
close.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: In this sentence, ‘the door’ is the object of close
close.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: In this sentence, ‘the door’ is the subject of close
close.translation[0].note_box[1].section: to stop being open, or to make something stop being open. You use close and shut especially about your eyes, your mouth, a door, a window, or a container
He closed the door gently, so as not to wake the children.
to close something. Shut sometimes has a feeling of doing something quickly and firmly, whereas close sounds more careful
He shut the door with a loud bang.
Shut your eyes and go to sleep.
to close a door or lid quickly and noisily, especially because you are angry
She left the room, slamming the door behind her.
to close curtains by pulling them across a window
The curtains were still drawn at ten o'clock in the morning.
to close a container by putting a lid onto it
Did you put the lid on the cookie jar?
to close something so that no air or water can get in or out
In this experiment, the chamber must be completely sealed.
close.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: not far from someone or something
close.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: If you need to buy bread or milk, the closest shop is about a mile away.
His eyes were small and close together.
There are several accounts of dolphins living in close proximity to humans  (=close to humans).
The victim had been shot at close range (=from very close).
Susan sat on a chair close to the window.
I don’t mind where we go on vacation as long as it’s close to a beach.
close.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Our birthdays are quite close together.
close.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: seeming very likely to happen or very likely to do something soon
close.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The two countries are close to signing a peace agreement.
We’re close to clinching the deal.
The old dog could barely whimper and seemed close to death.
The prosecution’s main witness was close to tears as she described the assault.
close.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: if two people are close, they like or love each other very much
close.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: My brother and I are very close.
Fiona and I have always been close friends.
I felt closer to Rob that evening than ever before.
close.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Fitt was the closest thing to a socialist in the party.
Their newest model bears a close resemblance to (=is very similar to) that of their rival competitor.
When I saw Henry with another woman I felt something close to jealousy.
close.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: looking at, thinking about, or watching something very carefully
close.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: She lifted up Jenny’s silver medallion to take a closer look.
You could have improved your answers by closer attention to detail.
Don’t worry, I’ll keep a close eye on the kids.
close.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: if a number or amount is close to another number or amount, it is not much higher or lower than it
close.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: We don’t know the exact figures, but about 10,000 might be a close approximation  (=close to the actual figure).
close.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: finishing or being played, fought etc with both sides almost equal
close.translation[1].definitions[7].note: a close second/third etc (=very nearly first, second etc)
close.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: It was a close game that could have gone either way.
The result is too close to call (=so close that it is impossible to know who will win).
close.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: used when you have only just managed to avoid something bad, dangerous, or embarrassing happening
close.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: ‘Phew, that was close, ’ Frank said as he swerved to avoid the cyclist.
United had a close shave when Liverpool almost scored.
close.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: very nearly getting, finding, or achieving something
close.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: At this point, the investigators were closer to the truth than they realized.
close.translation[1].definitions[10].def: relating to a situation in which people work well with each other or talk to each other often
close.translation[1].definitions[10].exa: He retained very close links with France throughout his life.
What we need now is closer cooperation between the club and supporters.
close.translation[1].definitions[11].def: with little or no space around something or between things
close.translation[1].definitions[11].exa: The horses are always eager for exercise after the close confinement of the stables.
The shoe is a close fit  (=there is no space around the foot).
I find it difficult to read such close print  (=with letters printed so close together).
close.translation[1].definitions[12].def: uncomfortably warm because there seems to be no air
close.translation[1].definitions[12].exa: The weather that night was hot and close, with a hint of thunder in the distance.
close.translation[1].definitions[13].def: unwilling to tell people about something
close.translation[1].definitions[13].exa: You’re very close about your work, aren’t you?
close.translation[1].definitions[14].exa: You won’t get a penny out of Jack – he’s very close with his money.
close.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 6: looking at, thinking about, or watching something very carefully
close.translation[1].note_box[0].section: She moved  forward to take a close look at the painting.
keep a close eye/watch on somebody/something
They have to keep a close eye on their finances.
A closer examination of the facts soon solved the mystery.
Their research involved a close study of two communities.
You will lose weight if you combine exercise with close attention to your diet.
The investigation included close scrutiny of the images on CCTV.
Closer inspection revealed that the rocks were from an earlier period.
Initially there will be close supervision of the trainee.
close.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Come a little closer, so you can see better.
Her father lives quite close by.
They were sitting close together on the couch.
A variety of good restaurants are close at hand (=very near).
James heard footsteps close behind him.
Ronnie sped off, with his brother’s car following close behind.
He drew her close to him.
close.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: near to the surface of something
close.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: An electric razor doesn’t really shave as close as a blade.
close.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: the end of an activity or of a period of time
close.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: At the close of trade, the Dow Jones index was 1.92 points down.
The monsoon season was drawing to a close (=ending).
The event came to a close (=finished) with a disco.
Finally the meeting was brought to a close (=ended).
close.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: used in street names for a road that has only one way in or out
close.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Take a left turn into Brown’s Close.
close.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: the area and buildings surrounding a cathedral
close.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: if a company, shop etc closes or someone closes it, it stops operating permanently
close.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: We have reluctantly decided to close the factory.
Banks are closing down branches by the hundred.
close.translation[5].definitions[1].defi: if a shop or building closes or someone closes it, it stops being open to the public for a period of time
close.translation[5].definitions[2].defi: if a share or currency closes at a particular value, it is worth that amount at the end of the day’s trading on a particular market
close.translation[5].definitions[2].exam: Amazon shares closed down at $29.56 on the NASDAQ.
The pound closed up slightly at $1.90130.
close.translation[5].definitions[3].defi: to finish on a particular date
close.translation[5].definitions[4].defi: to reach the point in a deal or sale where everyone involved agrees to it
close.translation[5].definitions[4].exam: The objective of the negotiation phase is to close the deal.
He had to lower his price in order to close the sale.
close.translation[5].definitions[5].defi: to stop having a particular account with a bank
close.translation[5].definitions[5].exam: Mr Samuels agreed to close the account and transfer the money to a company account.
close.translation[5].definitions[6].defi: to calculate the financial results at the end of a particular accounting period
close.translation[5].definitions[6].exam: On Friday the company closed the books on its fiscal first quarter.
close.translation[5].definitions[7].defi: if an investor or dealer on a financial market closes a position, they buy or sell the stocks, shares, currencies etc that they have agreed to buy or sell, even if this means that they lose money
close.translation[5].definitions[7].exam: If a dealer buys a futures contract and its price declines, he buys another at a lower price rather than closing out his position.
close.translation[6].definitions[0].defi: the end of the day’s activity, for example on the stockmarket or in a bank
close.translation[6].definitions[0].exam: At the close, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had climbed 17.49.
The dividend was payable to shareholders on the Register of Members at close of business on 7th May.
